texts.shortText: Tiny, flattened, red, elongate-oval benthic copepods with very short antennae. Best identified in the field by their habit of scuttling around in large numbers on the fronds of tongue-weed Gigartina polycarpa and other similar flat-bladed algae. Barely at the limit of visibility with the naked eye, so often overlooked, but extremely common once noticed.

Global: Thought to be endemic (but very poorly studied).

Local/Regional: Algoa Bay to at least Cape Peninsula, probably extending up west coast.

Development typically takes 3-4 weeks and the adults live a few months.  This species is extremely abundant on the frond of intertidal seaweeds and migrates out along the fronds when underwater, then moved back to the bases when in the air.
Thought to feed on fine organic matter, probably including bacteria, protozoa, mucus, etc.

Sexes are separate and copulating pairs are commonly seen. The male deposits sperm in a spermatophore that is cemented to the genital opening of the female and the eggs are fertilized as they are laid. They are then held in a single ventral sac while they develop.
Benthic copepods are very poorly studied in the region, but are commonly seen on the undersides of rocks, on shells and algae etc, so there are likely many other species that remain un-described.

Gibbons, MJ (1989). Tidal migration of Porcellidium (Copepoda: Harpacticoida) on fronds of the rocky shore alga Gigartina radula (Esper) J. Agardh (Gigartinales: Rhodophyta). South African Journal of Marine Science, 8(1), 3-7.

Hicks, GRF (1982). Porcellidiidae and Peltidiidae (Copepoda: Harpacticoida) from the marine algae of St Croix Island, Algoa Bay, South Africa. Zoological Journal of the Linnean Society, London, 75(1), 49-90.
